title.narrative: Campaigns addressing Gender Norms in COVID-19

description.narrative: A. Action Research A qualitative inquiry to (1) surface gender norms or narratives on unpaid care work and breadwinning among urban millennials in the midst of the pandemic; (2) highlight how they have challenged these; and (3) determine what various stakeholders can do to support and promote shared responsibilities in UCW and breadwinning. Focus group discussions, and key informant interviews will be conducted to supplement findings from the Social Norms Attitudes and Practices Survey (SNAPS) and SNAPS 2.0 and to inform a robust social media campaign. B. Social Media Campaign Oxfam shall employ social media campaign strategies based on solid experience and lessons from two successful social media campaigns on unpaid care work. These are "I laba Yu" campaign and "How I care Campaign." The objectives of this campaign would be to: • Engage a community of influencers towards deepening knowledge on positive deviance on UCW and breadwinning among urban millennials; • Create and strengthen partnerships among and between social media influencers, private sector and public relations firm to promote positive social norm shifts, and provide a supportive environment for shared UCW and breadwinning responsibilities; • Inform a broader population of urban millennials in the formal sector on positive gender norms on UCW and breadwinning in the time of COVID -19. Oxfam's approach to influencing and public engagement explores creative strategies and human -centred design. To challenge traditional thinking on UCW and breadwinning, the following key messages will be delivered to an initial target of 20 million urban millennials (48% of the Filipino millennials ) across all media and social media platforms: Care work is team work: Focus on encouraging and recognizing men's contribution in care work to promote redistribution of UCW in the household.
